Phosphate-containing alkali metal-doped TbOx/MgO catalysts for the oxidative coupling of methane Andrew S. Jones Nicolas Alfonso Vargas Helena E. Hagelin Weaver ⁎ Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Florida, Gainesville, FL 32611, USA Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Florida Gainesville FL 32611 USA Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Florida, Gainesville, FL, 32611, USA ⁎ Corresponding author. Addition of phosphate to alkali-metal (AM) doped terbium oxide (TbOx) supported on MgO was shown to improve both activity (methane conversion) and selectivity to C2+ products (ethane, ethylene and higher hydrocarbons) in the oxidative coupling of methane at reaction temperatures above 600 °C. The largest improvement upon phosphate addition was observed over the K-doped TbOx/MgO catalyst, and the K(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO catalyst is not very sensitive to K content (between K:Tb ratios of 1.2 and 2.0). Above 700 °C, the highest activity and C2+ selectivity were observed over the Li(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO catalysts. It was shown that TbOx is a necessary component and Tb2O3 is essential for a high activity and selectivity over these catalysts. Moreover, the C2H4 yield is significantly improved over the Li(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO catalysts, and the stability with time-on-stream higher, compared with the Li-TbOx/MgO catalyst, as long as the lithium and phosphate concentrations are not too high. Graphical Abstract Keywords Oxidative Coupling of Methane Alkali Metal with Phosphate and Terbium Oxide Supported on MgO CO2 Adsorption-Desorption X-Ray Diffraction Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The oxidative coupling of methane (OCM) is a one-step synthesis route to the production of ethane and ethylene, and the latter is a valuable feedstock in numerous industrially relevant products [1–6]. Early work in OCM research focused on doping of alkali metals into basic oxides and revealed that the addition of lithium to magnesium oxide produces an active catalyst with elevated C2+ selectivity [7,8]. However, stability is an issue with the Li-MgO catalyst due to the volatility of LiOH during the OCM reaction [9–14]. To improve stability, other alkali metals (AMs) or alkaline earth metals (AEMs) have been, and continue to be, used together with MgO and other oxides, in particular rare earth oxides [15–30]. More complex mixed oxides, such as perovskites, pyrochlores or fluorites have also been investigated recently [31–40], and in recent years a lot of focus has also been devoted to the promising Mn-Na2WO4/SiO2 catalyst [35,41–43] and various combinations of this catalyst [44–61], which display high activity and selectivity in addition to stability with time-on-stream. However, this catalyst requires temperatures on the high end of typical OCM reaction conditions (i.e. on the order of 800 ℃) and is very complex, as evidenced in the large volume of literature on this catalyst (a few more recent examples, in addition to those referenced above, include [5,62–71]). It is evident in the references cited above, as well as several reviews [72–79], that the effects of cations or cation combinations on the catalytic properties of oxide catalysts have been evaluated extensively in the search for more active and selective OCM catalysts. With the exception of carbonates, which tend to be prevalent on basic oxides [30,80,81], and the WO4 2- present in the Mn-Na2WO4/SiO2 catalyst, fewer studies examine the effects of different anions on the OCM activity and selectivity [82–89]. Halides of alkali metals or alkaline earth metals can be beneficial in the OCM reaction [90–97], but stability is often an issue also for this category of additives as halides tend to be removed during reaction conditions [98–103]. Another potential additive is phosphorus, or more specifically phosphate or pyrophosphate, although the benefits of adding phosphates to OCM catalysts appear to be dependent on the other components and the reaction conditions [83,84,89,104–122]. Furthermore, similar to the Li/MgO catalyst, the stability of phosphate- or pyrophosphate-containing catalysts with time-on-stream can be an issue [109,111,113]. This is particularly true for catalysts based on Li3PO4 as they have been shown to rapidly deactivate at elevated temperatures, although this rapid deactivation can in some cases be mitigated by adding other components, such as Ca to the Li3PO4 [114,118]. We have shown previously that a Li-doped TbOx/MgO catalyst is promising in the OCM reaction, as the activity and selectivity are higher at temperatures above 500 °C compared with the non-doped TbOx/MgO catalyst and the Li-TbOx/MgO catalyst is more stable than typical Li-containing catalysts [16]. To evaluate if the performance of the Li-TbOx/MgO catalyst can be further improved, phosphate addition to this catalyst was evaluated in the current study. Additional alkali metals, Na and K, were also included to determine if Na-TbOx/MgO or K-TbOx/MgO catalysts with added phosphate would be more efficient or stable compared with the Li-doped phosphate-containing catalyst, and the importance of TbOx was investigated by examining alkali-metal-doped phosphate-containing MgO nanoparticles with and without TbOx. Finally, alkali metal loadings in OCM catalysts are often reported in percent by weight, which means that the molar concentrations of these catalysts are very different, and this is particularly evident for Li due to its low molecular weight. Therefore, a set of catalysts with the same molar ratio of AM:Tb was also included. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst synthesis Terbia (TbOx) based catalysts, without phosphate or alkali metal (AM), were synthesized via incipient wetness impregnation onto a magnesium oxide nanoparticles support: MgO (Nanostructured and Amorphous Materials Inc., MgO 100 nm) using an aqueous solution of the terbium precursor (terbium (III) nitrate hexahydrate, 99.9 % REO, Alfa Aesar). The loading was 20 % Tb4O7 by weight, or 17.5 wt% of Tb, on the MgO support. However, the exact oxidation state of the terbium ions in the oxide is not known, but it is likely between Tb4O7 and TbO2. Furthermore, Tb2O3 has been identified on catalysts after reaction [16]. We therefore refer to our terbium oxide as TbOx (where 1.5 ≤ x ≤ 2.0). Alkali metal doped TbOx/MgO (AM-TbOx/MgO) catalysts were synthesized using a previously described method [16,18] , in which the Tb(NO3)3·6 H2O and the specific alkali metal precursor (LiNO3, NaNO3, or KNO3) were dissolved in a volume equal to the pore volume of the MgO support (incipient wetness impregnation). The pore volume was determined by adding water to 1 g of MgO support until it turned into a paste. The dissolved precursors were then added dropwise to the MgO support while stirring. The resulting sample was dried at 105 °C before being calcined in air at 800 °C for four hours. The composition of these catalysts were 2.5:17.5:77.5 AM:Tb:MgO weight ratio to keep the composition the same as in the previous study [16]. Catalysts containing an alkali metal and phosphate ions were synthesized using a sequential impregnation method, where the alkali metal and phosphate ions were added first via a wet impregnation method. Lithium carbonate (Puratonic, 99.998 % metal basis), sodium carbonate (Aldrich, 99.995 %), or potassium carbonate (Puratonic, 99.997 % metal basis) was dissolved in 50–100 ml of deionized (DI) water. The alkali metal loading used for this series of catalysts was equal to 5.0 % by weight. For simplicity the weight ratio of the catalysts were kept constant at 5:17.5:77.5 AM:Tb:MgO, i.e., ignoring the oxygens in TbOx and any added phosphate. A dilute solution of phosphoric acid (H3PO4, 1.457 M) was then added dropwise to the aqueous alkali carbonate solutions. The amount of phosphoric acid added varied between 0.4 and 2.2 ml depending on the amount of alkali metal added to the specific catalyst, to obtain an AM:PO4 molar ratio of roughly four, i.e., slightly less than the phosphate required to form Li3PO4, Na3PO4, or K3PO4 (where AM:PO4 = 3) to avoid excess phosphate. The MgO support (1.4 g) was then added to the solution of alkali metal carbonate and phosphoric acid, and the solvent evaporated at 85 °C under vigorous stirring. After drying, terbium nitrate was added to the AMzCO3(PO4)y/MgO materials using the incipient wetness impregnation method. Since the catalysts were not calcined before the second impregnation, it is expected that the terbium nitrate solution would redissolve and mix with some of the alkali carbonates and phosphate ions. The resulting catalysts were then dried at 105 °C overnight before being calcined in air at 800 °C for four hours. The amounts of Tb and MgO used to synthesize the catalysts were kept the same in all catalysts, i.e., 0.87 g of Tb(NO3)3·6 H2O of precursor was used with 1.4 g of MgO, to keep the Tb:MgO ratio constant. To determine the importance of Tb in these catalysts, phosphate-containing Na/MgO and K/MgO catalysts were prepared the same way as described above for the K(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO and Na(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO catalysts, except without the Tb addition step. A Li(PO4)y/MgO material was also synthesized, but it melted during calcination and fused to the crucible. It was therefore excluded from the study as it was not a stable material. Since the catalysts with a constant alkali metal content by weight result in very different molar ratios of AM:Tb (and AM:MgO ratios), additional phosphate-containing catalysts were also synthesized in which the AM:Tb content was kept constant at a molar ratio of two, which matches that of Na:Tb in a catalyst with a composition of 5:17.5:77.5 AM:Tb:MgO by weight, AM(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO(wt). Since an AM:Tb molar ratio of two results in a lower Li content, but higher K content compared with the AM(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO(wt) catalysts, the Li and K-containing catalysts are labeled according to the AM content to facilitate comparisons. The Li(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO catalyst with a 5 wt% Li loading has a high Li-to-Tb ratio (6.5) and is labelled Li(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO-(HL) (HL for High Li), while the lithium catalyst with the lower Li content (Li:Tb = 2.1) is referred to as Li(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO(LL) (LL for Low Li). In the case of the K-containing catalysts, the K(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO with a K-to-Tb ratio of 2.0, has a higher potassium content (K(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO(HK)) than the catalysts with 5 wt% of potassium (K:Tb = 1.2), denoted as K(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO(LK), i.e., HK for High K and LK for Low K. The AM:Tb ratios of all catalysts have been added to Table 1. 2.2 OCM reaction experiments Catalytic activity measurements were carried out in a quartz tube reactor with an inner diameter of 10 mm using a previously reported reactor system [18,123]. Each catalyst was pressed into a pellet, using a Carver pellet press, then crushed and sieved to a size range of 180–250 microns. For loading the reactor, 400 mg of the sieved catalyst was supported in the quartz reactor tube between two pieces of quartz wool. During reaction, CH4, O2, and an internal standard (N2) were fed through the system at a rate of 160 standard cm3 (sccm) (with N2 constant at 25.4 sccm) using three mass flow controllers (MFCs), which results in a GHSV of 2400 h−1. The CH4:O2 feed ratio was held constant at 4:1 for all experiments, as this is the stoichiometric amount needed for conversion of methane to ethane and water, and it was also shown to give the highest CH4 conversion at a reasonable C2 selectivity in a previous study [123]. The catalytic activity and selectivity were evaluated as a function of temperature from 500 to 800 °C with a 50 °C step size. Selected catalysts were also tested for stability during eight hours on stream at 750 °C. Products were quantified using a custom-configured, on-line Agilent 6890 N gas chromatograph equipped with both a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and a flame ionization detector (FID), and at each temperature two data points were collected and averaged. As described previously [18], we report two methane conversions, one based on the overall methane converted ( X CH 4 ) calculated using Eq. 1, and one based on the methane converted to COx (CO and CO2) and C2+ (C2H6, C2H4 and higher hydrocarbons) products ( X CH 4 * ) as shown in Eq. 2. The C2+ selectivity is based on the quantified COx and C2+ products (Eq. 3), while the C2H4 selectivity is calculated according to Eq. 4. To obtain a more accurate number, the C2+ yield is calculated using X CH 4 * (Eq. 5). (1) X CH 4 = CH 4 , in − CH 4 , out CH 4 , in (2) X CH 4 * = [ 2 · C 2 H 6 + C 2 H 4 + 3 · C 3 H 8 + CO + CO 2 ] out CH 4 , in (3) S C 2 + = CH 4 reacted t o C 2 and C 3 products CH 4 reacted t o CO x , C 2 , and C 3 products (4) S C 2 H 4 = CH 4 reacted t o C 2 H 4 CH 4 reacted t o CO x , C 2 , and C 3 products (5) Y C 2 + = X CH 4 * · S C 2 + 2.3 Surface area analysis Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area measurements were performed on all catalysts using a single-point isotherm on a ChemBET 3000 instrument operating at liquid nitrogen temperatures. In these experiments, 250 mg of catalyst was loaded into a quartz u-tube and was outgassed under a He flow at 800 °C for one hour before cooling down to room temperature under inert flow (He). Following outgassing of the sample a background flow of 30 % N2 with a balance of helium was introduced. The sample was then immersed in liquid N2, for approximately five minutes to allow for gas-phase nitrogen to adsorb on the surface of the catalyst. The sample was heated to room temperature by immersing the u-tube in room temperature water before BET measurements. The volume of N2 adsorbed was determined by injecting known volumes of pure N2 gas to match the desorption curve obtained during the previous heating step and the BET specific surface areas were calculated using the cross sectional area of a nitrogen molecule (0.162 nm2) [124]. 2.4 Temperature programmed desorption of CO2 Temperature programmed desorption (TPD) of CO2 was performed on a ChemBET 3000 instrument after a CO2 exposure at elevated temperature. In these experiments, 250 mg of catalyst was loaded into a quartz u-tube and was outgassed under a He flow at 800 °C for one hour prior to CO2 exposure at 200 °C for one hour. Physically absorbed CO2 was then removed by flowing helium over the catalyst at 200 °C for one hour, before the catalyst was heated to 800 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min, and the desorption of CO2 monitored. Temperature measurements were recorded by a thermocouple inside the quartz u-tube (on the outlet side) and a thermal conductivity detector measured the amount of desorbed gas. 2.5 X-ray diffraction analysis Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were acquired for the catalysts using a PANalytical X’Pert Powder Pro l diffractometer in Bragg-Brentano geometry. The setup was equipped with a secondary Ni filter, Cu Kα1,2 radiation and an X’Celerator multi strip detector. Data were collected between 2θ angles of 20 and 80º with a time per step of 10 ms and a step size of 0.08º. Identification of observed peaks was determined by comparing against known standards. 3 Results and discussion The goal of this study was to investigate the effects of phosphate addition in an attempt to further improve the activity, selectivity, and catalyst stability of the previous Li-TbOx/MgO catalyst [18]. As previous results have shown that the Li-TbOx/MgO catalyst is less stable than Na-TbOx/MgO, sodium and potassium were also included in the investigation. Magnesium oxide was chosen as the support oxide to reduce the concentration of expensive rare earth oxide, in this case terbia or TbOx, which is important for potential commercial applications. To determine the importance of terbia in these catalysts, alkali metal and phosphate precursors were also co-impregnated on pure MgO, i.e. without terbia, and these catalysts were included for comparison. 3.1 OCM reaction results 3.1.1 Alkali metal doped TbOx/MgO The reaction data obtained over alkali metal-doped TbOx/MgO are presented in Fig. 1. OCM results from Li- and Na-doped TbOx/MgO catalysts have been reported previously [18], but the data in Fig. 1 were obtained using MgO nanoparticles from a different supplier (Nanostructured and Amorphous Materials Incorporated, MgO-NA), since MgO nanoparticles from the previous supplier (Nanoscale Incorporated, MgO-NS) were no longer available. It is evident that the two MgO nanoparticle oxides are not the same, and that the MgO support is important in the overall OCM performance. Data obtained from these supports reveal that the MgO-NS nanoparticles are more active than the MgO-NA, and, while the activity difference is smaller when alkali metals and TbOx are added, the Li-TbOx/MgO-NA catalyst is slightly less active and selective compared with the Li-TbOx/MgO-NS catalyst, particularly between 600 and 700 °C (Figure S1). The differences could be due to trace amounts of impurities in the two MgO samples, since small amounts of dopants can have substantial effects on OCM performance [10]. While the AM-TbOx/MgO catalysts in the current study (with MgO-NA) are slightly less active compared with the AM-TbOx/MgO-NS in the previous study, the trends are the same. More specifically, the addition of TbOx improves both the activity and selectivity over bare MgO-NA below 800 °C (Fig. 1). Addition of Li, Na and K further improves the performance of the TbOx/MgO catalysts, although the light-off temperature is increased compared with the TbOx/MgO catalyst (Fig. 1) [18]. A temperature of 550 ℃ is needed for Li-TbOx/MgO and K-TbOx/MgO catalysts to outperform the TbOx/MgO catalyst, while Na-TbOx/MgO catalyst requires a temperature of 600 °C. The increase in methane conversion appears to be independent on specific alkali metal, while the improvement in selectivity to C2+ and C2H4 increases in the following order: K < Na < Li. This trend is expected from the literature [18], although the differences between the Na and Li are not as significant as those reported in the past over the MgO-NS support. While this trend could be due to the properties of the alkali metals, as the basic strength follows the same order, it could also be due to the alkali metal content. At a constant AM loading of 2.5 % by weight, the molar concentration of Li is higher than that of Na followed by K. It also appears that the K-TbOx/MgO catalyst is less stable at the higher temperatures, as a drop in both activity and selectivity is observed above 700 ℃. As can be seen in Table 1, the best catalyst in this set is the Li-TbOx/MgO, as expected. There is a small difference between the overall methane conversion ( X CH 4 ) and the methane converted to C2+ and COx products ( X CH 4 * ) for all catalysts (Table S1). The main reason for this discrepancy is carbon deposition downstream of the reactor bed (likely due to decomposition of the C2+ products (as they are easier to break down than CH4). Even though this underestimates the C2+ product yields, we report only X CH 4 * in the figures (and Table 1) as we feel this is more accurate. It is also evident in Table 1 that the selectivity to C2H4 increases with temperature for all catalysts, and the selectivity to all C2+ products goes through a maximum at 750 °C for most catalysts. The only exceptions are the bare MgO support, where the activity and selectivity continue to increase beyond 750 ℃, and the K-TbOx/MgO catalyst for which the selectivity goes through a maximum at 700 ℃. 3.1.2 MgO-supported alkali metal phosphate catalysts The higher alkali metal content together with the phosphate ions added to the AM-TbOx/MgO catalysts increase the maximum C2+ yield obtained from these catalysts compared with the original AM-TbOx/MgO catalysts (Table 1), but only at higher temperatures (above 600–650 °C). It appears that the higher alkali metal content and added phosphate increase the light-off temperature ( Fig. 2) compared with the AM-TbOx/MgO catalysts with the lower alkali metal content and no phosphate added (Fig. 1). The AM(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO catalysts are not active in the oxidative coupling of methane below 600 ℃ (Fig. 1). In most cases the higher C2+ yield is due to an increase in both CH4 conversion and C2+ selectivity over the AM(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO catalysts (Table 1), and the largest increase in C2+ yield is observed over the K(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO catalysts. The result is a smaller difference in catalytic performance between the various AM(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO catalysts at reaction temperatures above 700 °C compared with the differences observed between the original AM-TbOx/MgO catalysts without phosphate (Figs. 1 and 2), and the performance is not particularly sensitive to the alkali metal loading ( Fig. 3). More specifically, the difference in activity and C2+ selectivity between the two K(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO catalysts (with K:Tb molar ratios of 1.2 and 2.0) is close to the error bars of the measurements. It is therefore likely that the improved performance above 650 °C is due to the added phosphate, and that phosphate limits the low temperature activity (below 650 °C). These conclusions are further supported by the results from the Li-containing TbOx/MgO catalysts. In this case, the Li-TbOx/MgO catalyst contains more lithium (Li:Tb = 3.3) compared with the Li(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO(LL) catalyst (Li:Tb = 2.1), while the Li(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO(HL) has the highest lithium content (Li:Tb = 6.5), and both Li(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO catalysts outperforms the Li-TbOx/MgO catalyst at temperatures above 700 °C (Figs. 1, 3, S2, and Table 1). Despite the increase in light-off temperature with phosphate addition, there is an advantage to adding phosphate to these catalysts, as the temperature at which the maximum C2+ yield is obtained is the same (750 °C), regardless of alkali metal content and added phosphate (Table 1). The best performing catalysts at a reaction temperature of 750 °C are the two Li(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO catalysts, as they have slightly better conversions and selectivities compared with the Na(PO4)y- and K(PO4)y-containing TbOx/MgO and TbOx/MgO catalysts (Table 1). The improvement over the Li-TbOx/MgO catalyst is mainly due to an increase in the CH4 conversion above 700 °C, as the C2+ selectivities are similar over the Li-TbOx/MgO and Li(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO catalysts (Figure S2). In contrast, both the activity and C2+ selectivity are significantly improved over the K(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO catalysts (Figure S3 and Table 1). In fact, both K(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO catalysts exhibit a better performance than the Na(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO catalyst (Fig. 3), while the opposite is true when no phosphate is used, i.e., Na-TbOx/MgO is a better catalyst than K-TbOx/MgO (Fig. 1). Another benefit of adding phosphate to these catalysts is the significantly higher ethylene selectivity obtained over the Li-(PO4)y and K(PO4)y-containing TbOx/MgO catalysts (Figs. 2 and 3). An ethylene to ethane ratio of 3.5:1 was observed over the Li(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO(HL) catalyst at 800 °C, and while this ratio is not always reported in the literature, most studies that do tend to report significantly lower ethylene to ethane ratios [55,74,78,85,89,91,93–98,102,109,114,115,117–119]. Very high ethylene to ethane ratios have been reported for a few catalysts [44,63,107,125], and can also be obtained by adding trichloromethane to the feed stream or large amounts of halides to the catalysts [86,90,92,99,101,103,110,113,116,126]. However, stability is often problematic when halides are added, and the high ethylene to ethane ratios sometimes comes at the expense of an overall lower C2+ selectivity [120]. The importance of TbOx in these catalysts was also investigated by evaluating the OCM performance of AM(PO4)y/MgO without added TbOx. The results have been included in Fig. 2, and reveal that the Na(PO4)y/MgO and K(PO4)y/MgO materials are active OCM catalysts at reaction temperatures of 700 °C and above. Once activated the Na(PO4)y/MgO and K(PO4)y/MgO catalysts can outperform the undoped TbOx/MgO catalyst. However, it is also evident that terbia is a necessary component in these catalysts, as the Na(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO and K(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO catalysts outperform the Na(PO4)y/MgO and K(PO4)y/MgO materials at all temperatures (Fig. 2). Terbia is particularly important for any low temperature activity (lower than 700 °C). It is also interesting to note that the AM(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO catalysts are more selective to C2+ than those without Tb, even though TbOx/MgO is not a very selective OCM catalyst. 3.1.3 Time-on-stream experiments for undoped and lithium doped catalysts Since lithium is volatile, or rather form volatile compounds, under reaction conditions, lithium-containing OCM catalysts are known to exhibit poor stability [9]. Therefore, the Li-containing catalysts were subjected to time-on-stream experiments at 750 °C for eight hours and compared with the performance of the TbOx/MgO catalyst without any added Li. A temperature of 750 °C was chosen for these experiments, since this is the optimum temperature for most catalysts in the study (higher methane conversion and C2+ selectivity compared with operation at 700 or 800 °C). Similar to previous results [41], the Li-TbOx/MgO catalyst is more stable than typical lithium-containing catalysts, but it does exhibit a small loss in selectivity with time-on-stream ( Fig. 4). After the first hour, the TbOx/MgO catalyst (without added lithium) is very stable for the remaining seven hours confirming that the new MgO support (MgO-NA) does not result in stability issues with extended time-on-stream. It is very evident in Fig. 4 that the Li(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO(HL) catalyst with the high Li loading does not yield a stable catalyst. After a slow and steady decline in both activity and selectivity during the first three hours on stream, both values drop drastically during the fourth hour on stream. Therefore, after four hours on stream, the activity and selectivity of the Li(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO(HL) catalyst has dropped to the values obtained from the undoped TbOx/MgO catalyst. Inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) analysis reveals that some loss in Li content is observed (Table S2), but it is not as drastic as would be expected from the observed loss in activity and selectivity (Fig. 4). It is therefore more likely that structural changes leading to a drastic loss in active sites occur during reaction. The initial activity and selectivity are very similar for both Li(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO catalysts, but in contrast to the catalyst with the higher lithium and phosphate content, the Li(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO(LL) catalyst exhibited a slight increase in both activity and selectivity during the first hour and remained very stable with time-on-stream after that initial period. A small loss in lithium is observed after reaction when compared with the fresh catalyst, but the loss is smaller than the observed loss over the Li(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO(LL) catalyst, and does not appear to affect the activity. This suggests that the added phosphate does have a stabilizing effect on the active sites in the Li-TbOx/MgO catalysts, while at the same time increasing both the activity and C2+ selectivity. The improved activity and selectivity may be due to the introduction of more effective active oxygen species in these catalysts. However, the loading of lithium and phosphate must be optimized, as too high concentrations are detrimental to the stability. 3.2 Catalyst characterization The various catalysts were subjected to catalyst characterizations to determine the effects of phosphate addition on catalyst properties of importance in the oxidative coupling of methane. 3.2.1 Surface area measurement (BET) Specific (BET) surface area measurements have been shown to be less important for the OCM reaction compared with typical reactions catalyzed by heterogeneous catalysts. However, the specific surface area (SSA) can still provide information about changes that occur during reaction. Therefore, the SSA for each catalyst, before and after reaction, was determined and the results are included in Table 1. The surface area of the magnesium oxide support (23.3 m2/g) was shown to be fairly stable under reaction conditions since the surface area after exposure to reaction conditions was 21.3 m2/g. A slight increase in surface area was observed following deposition of TbOx onto the support, and the surface area of the TbOx/MgO catalyst is also stable during reaction (Table 1) as expected from the time-on-stream experiment. Doping with alkali metal ions or alkali phosphates in all cases, i.e. with or without TbOx, decreased the specific surface area of the MgO-supported catalysts by a factor of two or three. While a lower surface area is expected after addition of alkali metals, such as Li and Na, the decrease is not as drastic as was previously observed for the Li-TbOx/MgO-NS and Na-TbOx/MgO-NS catalysts [18]. In general, the potassium-containing catalysts have higher specific surface areas compared with their lithium- and sodium-containing analogues (Table 1). Adding phosphate to the catalysts does not have a significant impact on the specific surface area, although the K(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO catalyst does have a slightly lower surface area compared with the K-TbOx/MgO catalyst. As may have been expected, the Li(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO(LL) catalyst with the lower loading of lithium has a higher surface area than the one with a higher lithium concentration (Li(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO(HL)). In contrast, the difference in surface areas between the two K(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO catalysts is insignificant, although this may have been expected due to the lower molar loadings of K. The surface areas of the catalysts in this study were surprisingly stable during reaction. Only small losses in surface areas were observed, at most 10–20 %, which is very different from those observed during reaction for our Sm2O3 xerogel catalysts [18,21]. The largest losses in surface area are observed over the K-containing catalysts, but their surface areas after reaction are still higher than their Li- and Na-containing analogues. As expected from the time-on-stream experiments, the Li(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO(LL) catalyst retains more of its original surface area compared with the Li(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO catalyst with the higher Li loading (Li(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO(HL)). However, the difference is not as drastic as expected from the time-on-stream experiments. In summary, there is no observed correlation between the measured specific surface areas (either before or after reaction) and the catalytic activity or selectivity. The alkali-doped catalysts in general have lower specific surface areas compared with the undoped TbOx/MgO catalyst, and the addition of phosphate only had a minor effect on the specific surface areas of the catalysts. The most significant effect of phosphate addition appears to be slightly more stable surface areas, as long as TbOx is present. 3.2.2 Temperature programmed desorption (TPD) of CO2 Carbon dioxide is an acidic probe molecule often used in temperature programmed desorption measurements to determine the number and the strength of basic sites on the surfaces of OCM catalysts. The higher the desorption temperature, the stronger the basic site and the area under the curve is proportional to the number of basic sites for each catalyst. Basic sites have been shown to be of importance in the OCM reaction and some trends between the number or strength of basic sites and the catalytic activity or selectivity have been observed, but there is no straightforward correlation between these properties [16,127–131]. CO2 desorption data for the TbOx/MgO catalysts without added phosphate are shown in Fig. 5. The MgO support only has a limited amount of relatively weak basic sites, as evidenced by the small CO2 desorption peak at a temperature of 400 °C. Since this MgO support was only active at temperatures above 750 °C, this may indicate that defect sites are formed during reaction at high temperature over this oxide, and these sites would not be probed during a 200 °C CO2 exposure. The larger number of weakly basic sites of this material after reaction, supports the suggestion that defect sites are introduced during reaction. Addition of TbOx to MgO increases the number of weakly basic sites and introduces new and more basic sites which result in a CO2 desorption peak at a higher temperature (745 °C). Since most catalysts in the current study have two main features in the CO2 TPD spectra, the number of basic sites were quantified in two different temperature regions, between 200 and 600 °C as well as 600–800 °C ( Table 2). Increasing the number and strength of basic sites is often beneficial for improved OCM performance, as long as the sites do not bind CO2 too strongly [18], and this is consistent with the higher activity and selectivity of the TbOx/MgO compared with the MgO support. Some restructuring that alters the basic sites occurs during the reaction also for the TbOx/MgO catalyst. A slight increase in both types of basic sites is observed and the peaks are more well-defined (Fig. 5). The more basic sites appear weaker than before reaction, as this CO2 desorption peak has shifted to 700 °C. Weakening of the strong basic sites may explain why the TbOx/MgO catalyst is active at a lower temperature compared with other catalysts, as fewer of the basic sites would be blocked by adsorbed CO2 during reaction. Adding potassium and sodium to the TbOx/MgO catalyst further increases the number of weakly basic sites (Table 2) and also introduces additional intermediate and some very strong basic sites (CO2 desorption as the temperature reaches 800 ℃). However, restructuring again occurs during reaction and after reaction two major types of basic sites remains on these catalysts, the weakly basic sites that are similar to those on the MgO support (and may be from exposed support) and strongly basic sites that results in CO2 desorption close to 800 ℃. The increase in strongly basic sites is consistent with the higher activity and selectivity after addition of Na and K, but does not explain the observed differences in OCM performance between the Na-TbOx/MgO and K-TbOx/MgO catalysts. As has been observed previously, addition of Li to TbOx/MgO results in a significant increase in both the number and the strength of basic sites, and, initially, this catalyst does not have any weak MgO-like basic sites. A few weakly basic sites have been introduced during reaction, likely from exposed MgO support, and some of the strongly basic sites have been altered to give one main CO2 desorption feature around 750 ℃. These basic sites appear to be beneficial for the OCM reaction and may explain why the Li-TbOx/MgO is the most active and selective catalyst. Therefore, the presence of similar and strong basic sites on all the AM-TbOx/MgO catalysts is consistent with their OCM performance being similar, but there is not a straightforward correlation between the number of these sites and the activity or the selectivity of these catalysts (Table 2 and Fig. 1). The addition of phosphate to alkali metal doped TbOx/MgO completely changes the surfaces of these catalysts, and the CO2 desorption profiles vary significantly with alkali metal identity ( Fig. 6). The K(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO(LK) catalyst before reaction has fewer basic sites than the TbOx/MgO catalyst, and most of them are of an intermediate strength (Fig. 6). However, the surface of the K(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO(LK) catalyst appears to undergo major restructuring during reaction. A large amount of strongly basic sites is present on the surface after reaction together with some weaker and likely MgO-related basic sites. In contrast, the Na(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO catalyst initially has a very large number of basic sites of varying strength with a CO2 desorption maximum around 600 ℃. However, these sites are also altered during reaction, and most of the basic sites resulting in CO2 desorption around 600 ℃ on the fresh catalyst are lost. Therefore, the main CO2 desorption features after reaction are due to the MgO-related basic sites (Tdes ≈ 400 ℃) and the strongly basic sites (Tdes ≈ 750 ℃), and the main features remaining are similar to those observed on the K(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO(LK). Therefore, it appears that the basic sites measured after reaction are more important than those on the fresh Na(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO and K(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO(LK) catalysts, since their catalytic properties in the OCM reaction are very similar (Figs. 2 and 6). In stark contrast, the fresh Li(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO(HL) catalyst displayed almost no CO2 desorption features in the temperature range investigated. This suggests that the MgO support is almost completely covered, and it also appears that the terbium sites are blocked on the Li(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO(HL) catalyst. This is likely due to the high Li:Tb ratio (6.5), and therefore also a high phosphate content, and suggests that the incipient wetness impregnation with the terbium precursor indeed redissolves the lithium and phosphate salts in the second synthesis step. It is also evident that this is not a surface area effect, since the specific surface areas before and after reaction are in the same range as for the other catalysts (Table 1). No major change in the CO2 desorption curve is observed after reaction. Since the Li(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO(HL) catalyst is amongst the most active of the AM(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO catalysts at higher temperatures (Fig. 2), it is possible that the Li(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO catalyst only has very basic sites, and that during the conditions of the CO2 TPD experiments temperatures in excess of 800 ℃ are required for CO2 desorption over this catalyst. However, considering the restructuring observed before and after reaction for the other AM(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO catalysts, a restructuring of the catalyst during reaction conditions is expected, potentially forming sites that cannot be measured under non-operating conditions (i.e. before and after reaction). However, operando CO2 TPD experiments are of course not possible, and, furthermore, in operando measurements are in general difficult at these high temperatures and harsh reaction conditions. No, or very little, CO2 desorption on these catalysts does indicate that removal of species blocking CO2 adsorption sites is difficult or CO2 is bound very strongly to the sites, and this would explain why the Li(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO catalyst does not exhibit any activity below 700 °C. It is also evident that the lithium or phosphate concentrations are not sufficiently high to block all the MgO and TbOx-related basic sites on the Li(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO(LL) catalyst with the lower lithium loading (Li:Tb = 2.1) (Fig. 6). Two CO2 desorption features are observed from the Li(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO(LL) catalyst and their positions suggest that they are associated with MgO and TbOx sites. It is interesting to note that the basic sites observed on the Li(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO(LL) catalyst are very different from those observed on the Li-TbOx/MgO catalyst. The presence of basic sites that desorb CO2 below 800 ℃ on the Li(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO(LL) catalyst is consistent with the higher activity at lower temperature compared with the Li(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO(HL) catalyst. However, the small CO2 desorption features (low number of basic sites) do not explain the high activity and selectivity observed over this catalyst. It is possible that this catalyst also has additional very strong basic sites that are not probed by heating to 800 ℃. Only a slight redistribution of sites is observed after reaction (more weakly basic sites are formed at the expense of the more basic sites), which is consistent with the high stability of Li(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO(LL) catalyst (vide infra). The fresh catalyst with the higher potassium loading, K(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO(HK) with K:Tb = 2.0, also has fewer basic sites than the TbOx/MgO catalyst before reaction. The desorption features on both K(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO catalysts are weak. However, just as for the K(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO(LK) catalyst, significant restructuring occurs during reaction. Therefore, after reaction the higher K content of the K(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO(HK) catalyst is evident in the larger CO2 uptake over this catalyst. The basic sites are of similar strength since the CO2 desorption temperatures are the same over the two K(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO catalysts, but, as mentioned, the peaks obtained from the K(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO(HK) catalysts are more intense. While a higher number of basic sites is consistent with the better performance of the K(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO(HK) catalyst compared with K(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO(LK), the activity difference is smaller than expected based on the number of basic sites. In summary, the CO2 desorption measurements before and after reaction reveal that significant restructuring of the phosphate-containing catalysts occurs during reaction, and measuring the number and strength of basic sites using CO2 adsorption and desorption before and after reaction does not appear to probe the active sites that are present under reaction conditions. This is consistent with recent conclusions that OCM catalysts are dynamic systems under reaction conditions [57], although in operando catalyst characterizations are challenging due to the harsh operating conditions. 3.2.3 X-ray diffraction analysis The XRD patterns obtained from the doped and undoped TbOx/MgO catalysts before and after reaction are shown in Figs. 7 through 9. The most intense peaks in the XRD patterns are those originating from the cubic magnesium oxide nanoparticle support. Peaks due to TbOx are also visible in the XRD patterns, and, consistent with previous studies [16,18], the terbium oxide with the best fit on the fresh catalysts is in all cases TbO1.81. Addition of alkali metal does not change the observed crystal structures, but results in slightly larger particles, as evidenced by the sharper and narrower peaks compared with the undoped TbOx/MgO catalyst. This is expected from the decrease in surface area observed after addition of alkali metal and is also consistent with previous studies. However, in contrast to earlier reports [16,18], no lithium carbonate is observed on the Li-TbOx/MgO catalyst in this study (Fig. 7). If present, other alkali metal containing compounds are below the detection limit of the XRD measurements (i.e., present in very small clusters or in an amorphous state). Additional TbOx-related peaks appear in the XRD patterns after reaction, and small shifts indicate a change in the oxidation state to Tb2O3, as previously observed [16,18]. This is an important change in oxidation state, as Tb2O3 is believed to be more selective to C2+ products in the OCM reaction compared with TbO2 or TbO1.81 [16]. In most cases, the addition of phosphate to the alkali metal doped TbOx/MgO catalysts does not change the TbOx phase observed on the fresh (TbO1.81) or spent (Tb2O3) catalysts (Figs. 8 and 9). The only exception is the Li(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO(HL) catalyst with the high lithium and phosphate loading. The lithium and phosphate loadings are so high on this catalyst that Li3PO4 can be observed in the XRD pattern, and, apparently, the terbium has reacted with the phosphate and formed Tb3PO7 (Fig. 8). Due to the high number of peaks observed in the XRD patterns obtained from the Li(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO(HL) catalyst, it is difficult to observe features from TbO1.81 and Tb2O3 on the fresh and spent catalysts. If present, they are close to the noise level in the XRD patterns from this catalyst. The low amount of TbOx on this catalyst may explain why higher temperatures are required to observe significant activity over this catalyst. The Li3PO4 and Tb3PO7 phases are still present on this catalyst after reaction, and the Tb3PO7 is slightly more pronounced after reaction. The presence of Tb3+ (rather than Tb4+) compounds could be beneficial to the selectivity over this catalyst. A small additional peak has also appeared after reaction, and it is reasonably consistent with Mg2P3. The presence of a small amount of Tb3PO7 cannot be excluded on the fresh Na(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO catalyst, but TbO1.81 is the major Tb-containing compound on this catalyst. After reaction there is no indication of a Tb3PO7 peak in the Na(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO, but a small peak identified as Mg2P3 is observed, and it appears to be more pronounced than the same peak in the spent Li(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO(HL) catalyst. No additional peaks, i.e. other than the ones due to MgO, TbO1.81 and Tb2O3, are observed in the XRD patterns obtained from the K(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO(LK) catalyst before and after reaction. The higher potassium and phosphate loadings on the K(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO(HK) catalyst yield XRD patterns that are very similar to those obtained from the K(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO(LK) catalyst. The introduction of K4P2O7 or K3Tb(PO4)2 compounds during reaction cannot be ruled out on the K(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO(HK) catalyst, but the peaks are too small for proper identification and the major phases on this catalyst are Tb2O3 and MgO after reaction (Fig. 9). For the catalyst with the lower loading of lithium and phosphate, Li(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO(LL), detecting Li3PO4 is very challenging, but small features appear to be present close to the noise level. The main TbOx phases on the Li(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO(LL) catalyst are the same as on the TbOx/MgO catalyst, i.e. TbO1.81 before and Tb2O3 after reaction. After reaction, there are indications of Tb3PO7 and Mg2P3, but the peaks are barely above the noise in the XRD pattern (Fig. 9). 4 Conclusions This study reveals that addition of phosphate to alkali-doped TbOx/MgO can yield catalysts that are more active and selective in the oxidative coupling of methane compared with alkali-doped TbOx/MgO without phosphate. However, the addition of phosphate only improves the performance at higher temperatures, more specifically above 650 °C. Below 650 °C, the alkali-doped TbOx/MgO without phosphate have both higher activity (CH4 conversion) and C2+ selectivity compared with those containing phosphate. The largest improvement upon phosphate addition was observed over the K-doped TbOx/MgO catalysts, and under the conditions used in this study the catalytic performance was not significantly affected by the potassium loading. However, the Li(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO were the best performing catalysts out of the AM(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO catalysts included in the study. While phosphate addition increased the light-off temperature, the temperature at which maximum conversion was observed remained at 750 °C for most catalysts, i.e. with or without added phosphate. Additionally, phosphate addition resulted in an improved ethylene selectivity, the more desirable OCM product, and maximum ethylene yields of 11.5 % and 10.6 % (48 % and 44 % selectivity to C2H4) were obtained at 800 °C over the Li(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO(HL) and Li(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO(LL) catalysts, respectively. Another significant benefit of phosphate addition, particularly for Li-containing OCM catalysts, is the higher stability with time-on-stream observed for the Li(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO(LL) catalyst compared with the Li-doped TbOx/MgO catalyst without phosphate. However, it is also evident that the lithium and phosphate concentrations must be optimized as the Li(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO(HL) catalyst was significantly less stable with time-on-stream. There is no straightforward correlation between the specific surface area or the number or strengths of basic sites measured via CO2 adsorption at 200 ºC and the activity or selectivity in the OCM reaction over these catalysts. This suggests that the CO2 adsorption at 200 ºC does not probe the active sites that are present during reaction, or that higher temperatures (>800 ºC) are required to remove strongly adsorbed CO2 molecules during the TPD measurement, but that these sites can still be accessed during reaction due to the presence of other reaction species. The CO2 desorption measurements before and after reaction do reveal that significant restructuring of the catalysts occurs during reaction, and this is most pronounced for the phosphate-containing catalysts. This study reveals that TbOx is a necessary component for high activity and selectivity in these catalysts, particularly for activity at lower temperatures, and the data in this study further supports that Tb2O3, which is present after exposure to reaction conditions, is important for the high activity and C2+ selectivity. However, Li, or another alkali metal, is necessary to obtain an effective OCM catalyst, and addition of phosphate can further improve CH4 conversion and C2+ selectivity of Li-TbOx/MgO catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Addition of phosphate to alkali-metal (AM) doped terbium oxide (TbOx) supported on MgO was shown to improve both activity (methane conversion) and selectivity to C2+ products (ethane, ethylene and higher hydrocarbons) in the oxidative coupling of methane at reaction temperatures above 600 °C. The largest improvement upon phosphate addition was observed over the K-doped TbOx/MgO catalyst, and the K(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO catalyst is not very sensitive to K content (between K:Tb ratios of 1.2 and 2.0). Above 700 °C, the highest activity and C2+ selectivity were observed over the Li(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO catalysts. It was shown that TbOx is a necessary component and Tb2O3 is essential for a high activity and selectivity over these catalysts. Moreover, the C2H4 yield is significantly improved over the Li(PO4)y-TbOx/MgO catalysts, and the stability with time-on-stream higher, compared with the Li-TbOx/MgO catalyst, as long as the lithium and phosphate concentrations are not too high.
coredata.dc:title: Phosphate-containing alkali metal-doped TbOx/MgO catalysts for the oxidative coupling of methane

dcterms:subject.$: Alkali Metal with Phosphate and Terbium Oxide Supported on MgO
